column6: Talens Rembrandt Extra Fine Artist' Oil
column7: A buttery oil that features excellent tinting strength, a high level of pigmentation for intense colours, and a uniform degree of gloss and thickness amongst colours. Easy to mix and use. These oils are great for beginners, students in advanced studies, and working artists.

column6: Talens Rembrandt Extra Fine Artist' Oil
column7: A cool yellow colour, Cadmium Lemon is a single pigment colour with excellent tinting abilities. Cadmium was discovered in 1817. Its stable opaque colours have made it a popular pigment ever since. Paul Gauguin painted ‘Breton Woman in Prayer’ in 1894 with a yellow lemon dress.

column6: Talens Rembrandt Extra Fine Artist' Oil
column7: Extra rich and fully opaque, Cadmium Yellow Deep is a vibrant light orange with luminous golden yellow tints. It has a masstone of vivid orangey yellow, with an undertone displaying a rich orangey yellow. A strong opaque deep yellow which is sensitive to moisture and should not be used outdoors. Yellow was Vincent Van Gogh's favourite colour and was said to be the colour of “self expression.”  In some of his paintings, he restricted his palette to be composed almost entirely of yellows, as in ‘Sunflowers’.

column6: Talens Rembrandt Extra Fine Artist' Oil
column7: Yellow Ochre is a warm yellow colour. Originally made from natural iron oxides found in earth, it is one of the oldest pigments used by mankind. A synthetic version became available in the 1920s. Ideal for mixing with other mineral pigments for sensitive greens or the subtle warming of flesh tones without adding shadow.

column6: Talens Rembrandt Extra Fine Artist' Oil
column7: Incredibly rich and opaque, this gorgeous red is a pure genuine Cadmium Red, warm, but also deeper in value, with an intensely captivating mass tone and softly warm tints. On the traditional colour wheel, it is considered to be a 'true red', close to vermilion. It is also considered a modern day replacement for vermilion, but it is more saturated (higher chroma) than genuine vermilion.

column6: Talens Rembrandt Extra Fine Artist' Oil
column7: Quinacridone Rose is a powerful, transparent rose pink. It can form part of a primary triad is it mixes to create beautiful purples and natural oranges, or can be used as the cool red in a split primary palette.  In Antiquity, Quinacridone Rose  was made from thousands of crushed kermes insects.

column6: Talens Rembrandt Extra Fine Artist' Oil
column7: Permanent Madder Medium has a masstone of a rich burgundy brown, with a burnt red brown undertone. It has an intense luminosity and depth due to the very fine grinding process, along with the highest possible concentration of pigments. It it lightfast and durable.

column6: Talens Rembrandt Extra Fine Artist' Oil
column7: Ultramarine is a rich transparent blue. It was created by French chemist Guimet in 1828 as a synthetic but chemically identical alternative to the expensive pigment derived from Lapis Lazuli. The pigment was considered more precious than gold. For centuries, the lone source of ultramarine was an arid strip of mountains in northern Afghanistan. Because of its prohibitive costs, the color was traditionally restricted to the raiment of Christ or the Virgin Mary.

column6: Talens Rembrandt Extra Fine Artist' Oil
column7: Phthalo Blue Green is an intense, deep blue with a green undertone. It is made from the modern pigment Phthalocyanine which was introduced in the 1930s.

column6: Talens Rembrandt Extra Fine Artist' Oil
column7: A brilliant transparent green pigment with a blue undertone. Invaluable for mixing. Add a cool or mid yellow for bright spring-greens, add a warm yellow for wonderful Sap greens. Add a crimson for the most amazing range of plum, aubergine, deep green and black hues. Add burnt sienna for pine greens. Add a blue for turquoise hues.

column6: Talens Rembrandt Extra Fine Artist' Oil
column7: A stable all-round black colour with brown undertones and excellent tinting powers. Its name stems from the traditional method for obtaining it - roasting elephant tusks. Swedish artist Anders Zorn is said to have used only ivory black, titanium white, cadmium red and yellow ochre. This quartet of colours is known as Zorn palette.

column6: Talens Rembrandt Extra Fine Artist' Oil
column7: A blue-black colour that is fairly smooth in texture and also denser than lamp black. Rembrandt loved bone black. Unmixed bone black pigment was used to paint the darkest parts of the clothing in his portrait of Phillips Lucasz and in ‘The Night Watchmen’.

Burnt Sienna is a rich brown pigment made by burning Raw Sienna. Named after Siena in Italy, where the pigment was sourced during the Renaissance, it is a transparent pigment with red-brown tones. It is one of the most useful colours in the palette. Mixed with Ultramarine it creates a warm Indigo, Burnt Umber hues, lovely greys, stormy sky colours, shadow colours and so on. With a yellow it creates raw sienna hues. With a phthalo blue it creates cool greys and browns. With a crimson it creates earthy indian reds and burnt reds...and so on. Alone, it creates a perfect skin tone.

A rich dark brown pigment, it is made from natural brown clays found in earth. It was named after Umbria, a region in Italy where it was mined. Burning the raw pigment intensifies its colour. The use of umber by artists dates back to our earliest image-making ancestors who smeared soil on cave walls as a suitable approximation for the auburn fur of beasts.

Used as a pigment since very earliest times. Carbon blacks are made by heating wood, or other plant material, with a very restricted air supply. Sticks of charcoal have been used for sketching by artists of all periods, and traces of their work may be found on the ground layer of paintings.

Developed in 1805 and entered the English market in the 1860s. Its name derives from the Latin Caeruleum meaning sky-blue pigment. It is a bright blue pigment with green undertones. Monet's 'The Gare Saint-Lazare' (1877) is a mixture of cobalt blue, cerulean blue, synthetic ultramarine, emerald green and viridian.

An opaque willow green pigment. Though discovered in 1809 it was only made available for artists in 1862. It is commonly used for camouflage clothing. This neutral and very opaque mid tone green, can be shifted in many directions when mixed with brighter colours. Useful in landscapes and for dulling red colours and making browns and mossy colours. Can be mixed with Burnt Umber to make shadows.

A versatile bright mid-range orange colour. Cadmium products have very high hiding power and good permanence. A cadmium orange was available as a commercial product from 1919. The pigment was used sparingly due to the scarcity of cadmium metal and was therefore extremely expensive. Munch’s The Scream utilised Cadmium Orange in the sky.
An intense red colour with orange undertones. It is an opaque single pigment colour with excellent tinting properties. A popular colour with Matisse.

Incredibly rich and opaque, this gorgeous red is a pure genuine Cadmium Red, warm, but also deeper in value, with an intensely captivating mass tone and softly warm tints. On the traditional colour wheel, it is considered to be a 'true red', close to vermilion. It is also considered a modern day replacement for vermilion, but it is more saturated (higher chroma) than genuine vermilion. Matisse was much taken with this strong new red, which has excellent stability. He recounts that he attempted, unsuccessfully, to persuade Renoir to adopt it in place of the traditional cinnabar.

The range of cadmium pigments are basically cadmium yellow (cadmium sulfide) with some selenium added in place of sulfur (cadmium selenide). Yellow was Vincent Van Gogh's favourite colour and was said to be the colour of “self expression.”  In some of his paintings, he restricted his palette to be composed almost entirely of yellows, as in ‘Sunflowers’.

Inspired by the flower native to Western Europe, this is the palest of four single pigment Cadmium Yellows. Yellow was Vincent Van Gogh's favourite colour and was said to be the colour of “self expression.”  In some of his paintings, he restricted his palette to be composed almost entirely of yellows, as in ‘Sunflowers'.

A clean blue pigment discovered in 1802 by French chemist Louis Jacques Thenard as an alternative pigment to the expensive Lapis Lazuli blue. Vincent van Gogh declared to his brother Theo, 'Cobalt Blue is a divine colour and there is nothing so beautiful for putting atmosphere around things' - it makes sense then, that Cobalt Blue is used most masterfully, and famously, in van Gogh's 'The Starry Night'.

The diarylide yellows are the most common yellow non-toxic pigments used in printing as well as a wide variety of other applications. A deep warm translucent yellow used as a replacement for Indian Yellow which was made from cow’s urine.
This lighter shade of Hansa is a popular replacement for Cadmium, although much more transparent. Yellow was Vincent Van Gogh's favourite colour and was said to be the colour of “self expression.”
Nickel Azo Yellow washes out to a lighter almost lemon yellow but has a deeper, slightly dirty masstone.
The greenish variation on this very powerful tinting versatile blue. When used thickly it is dark and opaque, but phthalo extends beautifully for glazes.

A brilliant transparent green pigment with a blue undertone. Invaluable for mixing. Add a cool or mid yellow for bright spring-greens, add a warm yellow for wonderful Sap greens. Add a crimson for the most amazing range of plum, aubergine, deep green and black hues. Add burnt sienna for pine greens. Add a blue for turquoise hues.
A brilliant Lime Green tone with a Yellow undertone that is ideal for use in landscapes and non-objective painting and an essential for low key painters.
A bright warm orange, Pyrrole orange is a semi-transparent colour. A single pigment colour, Pyrrole Orange is a clean mid-orange which mixes well with other colours.
Pyrrole Red is a single pigment colour. It is a warm mid-range red, opaque and highly permanent. It is a medium red that has more chroma than cadmium red and is also opaque and permanent.
Quinacridone Magenta is a rich deep violet-red colour. It is based on the Quinacridone pigment. The name Magenta comes from a lake colour named in 1859 after the battle in Magenta, Italy.
Quinacridone Red is a vivid mid-red colour. It is a transparent pigment.
A bright brown pigment. One of the oldest pigments, it can be found in prehistoric cave art. It is named after Siena, Italy where the pigment was sourced during the Renaissance.
A rich brown pigment made by the natural brown clays found in earth. It was named after Umbria, a region in Italy where it was mined.
Red Ochre is one of the oldest pigments used by man. Originally made from natural iron oxides found in the earth, it is an opaque brownish red pigment. It was often used in Michelangelo's drawings.
A warm opaque white colour with strong brown undertones. Popular in portrait painting to create a realistic skin tone when combined with Burnt Sienna and Potters Pink.

A buttery oil that features excellent tinting strength, a high level of pigmentation for intense colours, and a uniform degree of gloss and thickness amongst colours. Easy to mix and use. These oils are great for beginners, students in advanced studies, and working artists.

Ultramarine is a rich transparent blue. It was created by French chemist Guimet in 1828 as a synthetic but chemically identical alternative to the expensive pigment derived from Lapis Lazuli. The pigment was considered more precious than gold. For centuries, the lone source of ultramarine was an arid strip of mountains in northern Afghanistan. Because of its prohibitive costs, the colour was traditionally restricted to the raiment of Christ or the Virgin Mary.

Ultramarine Violet is a rich purple colour. It is a derivation of French Ultramarine, a synthetic pigment created in 1828 by French chemist Guimet as an alternative to genuine Ultramarine. The colour violet only became common in modern art with the rise of the French Impressionists because pigments were not previously available or were too expensive.

Yellow Ochre is a warm yellow colour. Originally made from natural iron oxides found in earth, it is one of the oldest pigments used by mankind. A synthetic version became available in the 1920s. Ideal for mixing with other mineral pigments for sensitive greens or the subtle warming of flesh tones without adding shadow.
Golden's interpretation of cyan is phthalo green-shade with a small amount of titanium white for use as a versatile and affordable mixing blue.
Another single-pigment quinacridone, Primary Magenta is a semi-opaque mixer that bridges red and violet.
Primary Yellow is a bright yellow gouache colour. It is one of the basic primary colours. It is based on the high tinting strength Quinophthalone yellow pigment.

Burnt Sienna is a rich brown pigment made by burning Raw Sienna. Named after Siena in Italy, where the pigment was sourced during the Renaissance, it is a transparent pigment with red-brown tones. It is one of the most useful colours in the palette. Mixed with Ultramarine it creates a warm Indigo, burnt umber hues, lovely greys, stormy sky colours, shadow colours and so on. With a yellow it creates raw sienna hues. With a phthalo blue it creates cool greys and browns. With a crimson it creates earthy indian reds and burnt reds...and so on. Alone, it creates a perfect skin tone.

An opaque orange single pigment colour with high tinting strength and good covering abilities. ‘The Scream’ by Edvard Munch depicts a human figure whose face is distorted by an expression of overwhelming terror and anxiety - the landscape behind the figure consists of a fiery Cadmium Orange sky above a bleak body of water.

An intense red colour with orange undertones. It is an opaque single pigment colour with excellent tinting properties. The Zorn palette refers to a palette of colours attributed to the great Swedish artist, Anders Zorn (18 February 1860 – 22 August 1920). It consists of just 4 colours being yellow ochre, ivory black, vermilion and titanium white. Cadmium red light is commonly used in place of vermilion by modern day artists.

Extra rich and fully opaque, Cadmium Yellow Deep is a vibrant light orange with luminous golden yellow tints. It has a masstone of vivid orangey yellow, with an undertone displaying a rich orangey yellow. A strong opaque deep yellow which is sensitive to moisture and should not be used outdoors Yellow was Vincent Van Gogh's favourite colour and was said to be the colour of “self expression.”  In some of his paintings, he restricted his palette to be composed almost entirely of yellows, as in ‘Sunflowers’.

Developed in 1805 and entered the English market in the 1860s. Its name derives from the Latin Caeruleum meaning sky-blue pigment. It is a bright blue pigment with green undertones. Monet's 'The Gare Saint-Lazare' (1877) is a mixture of cobalt blue, cerulean blue, synthetic ultramarine, emerald green and viridian.

A single pigment opaque bright blue green, named after the semi-precious stone that was exported to Europe from Persia via Turkey. Van Gogh’s ‘Blossoming Almond Tree’ utilised Cobalt Teal for its background.

A stable all-round black colour with brown undertones and excellent tinting powers. Its name stems from the traditional method for obtaining it - roasting elephant tusks. Swedish artist Anders Zorn is said to have used only ivory black, titanium white, cadmium red and yellow ochre. This quartet of colours is known as Zorn palette.

A light warm red single pigment colour, which is semi-opaque. Naphthol is a modern synthetic organic pigment developed in the early 20th century. Rothko dabbled with untested pigments in his work incorporating two brand-new organic reds into his palette for a series of murals. Naphthol, had no ill effects while Lithol faded badly.
A rich red-purple colour which is semi-opaque and made of multiple pigments. The name magenta comes from a lake colour named in 1859 after the battle in Magenta, Italy.
A light and vibrant green-yellow opaque colour, made up of a number of pigments including phthalocyanine green.
An intense deep blue single pigment colour with a green undertone. It's made from the modern synthetic pigment phthalocyanine which was introduced in the 1930s.

A brilliant transparent green single pigment colour with a yellow undertone. It's made from the modern synthetic pigment phthalocyanine which was introduced in the 1930s and has a high tinting strength.
A bright brown pigment. One of the oldest pigments, it can be found in prehistoric cave art. It is named after Siena, Italy where the pigment was sourced during the Renaissance.

A clean blue pigment. Genuine Cobalt was discovered in 1802 by French chemist ThĂ©nard as an alternative pigment to the expensive Lapis Lazuli blue. A clean blue pigment discovered in 1802 by French chemist Louis Jacques Thenard as an alternative pigment to the expensive Lapis Lazuli blue. Vincent van Gogh declared to his brother Theo, 'Cobalt Blue is a divine colour and there is nothing so beautiful for putting atmosphere around things' - it makes sense then, that Cobalt Blue is used most masterfully, and famously, in van Gogh's 'The Starry Night'.

A buttery oil that features excellent tinting strength, a high level of pigmentation for intense colours, and a uniform degree of gloss and thickness amongst colours. Easy to mix and use. These oils are great for beginners, students in advanced studies, and working artists.

A vivid bright red-purple colour which is highly opaque and made of multiple pigments. The name magenta comes from a lake colour named in 1859 after the battle in Magenta, Italy. Used by Mark Rothko in the painting entitled ‘Magenta, Black, Green on Orange’.

A light green-yellow opaque colour. Made up of three pigments, this colour recreates the true gem pigment which was popular with artists including Picasso, but phased out due to safety issues in the second half of the twentieth century
A light and vivid yellow-green opaque colour, made up of a blend of pigments including phthalocyanine.
The Light Blue Permanent colour is uniquely formulated to bring out the maximum brilliance and clarity of pigment.

The range of cadmium pigments, yellow, orange and red are basically cadmium yellow (cadmium sulfide) with some selenium added in place of sulfur (cadmium selenide). Monet used this colour extensively.

Burnt Sienna is a rich brown pigment made by burning Raw Sienna. Named after Siena in Italy, where the pigment was sourced during the Renaissance, it is a transparent pigment with red-brown tones. It is one of the most useful colours in the palette. Mixed with Ultramarine it creates a warm Indigo, burnt umber hues, lovely greys, stormy sky colours, shadow colours and so on. With a yellow it creates raw sienna hues. With a phthalo blue it creates cool greys and browns. With a crimson it creates earthy indian reds and burnt reds...and so on. Alone, it creates a perfect skin tone.

A rich dark brown pigment, it is made from natural brown clays found in earth. It was named after Umbria, a region in Italy where it was mined. Burning the raw pigment intensifies its colour. The use of umber by artists dates back to our earliest image-making ancestors who smeared soil on cave walls as a suitable approximation for the auburn fur of beasts.

A rich dark red, Cadmium Red Deep Hue is a carefully selected combination of pigments closely resembling genuine Cadmium Red Deep.Matisse was much taken with this strong new red, which has excellent stability. He recounts that he attempted, unsuccessfully, to persuade Renoir to adopt it in place of the traditional cinnabar.
Cadmium Yellow Deep Hue is a warm yellow colour with orange undertones. It is a carefully selected combination of pigments closely resembling genuine Cadmium Yellow Deep.

The range of cadmium pigments, yellow, orange and red are basically cadmium yellow (cadmium sulfide) with some selenium added in place of sulfur (cadmium selenide). Monet used this colour extensively.

A clean blue pigment discovered in 1802 by French chemist Louis Jacques Thenard as an alternative pigment to the expensive Lapis Lazuli blue. Vincent van Gogh declared to his brother Theo, 'Cobalt Blue is a divine colour and there is nothing so beautiful for putting atmosphere around things' - it makes sense then, that Cobalt Blue is used most masterfully, and famously, in van Gogh's 'The Starry Night'.
A transparent rich mid-range crimson colour. In antiquity, Crimson dyes were made from thousands of crushed kermes insects. Later, crimson was also made from Alizarin, the first synthetic red dye.

A transparent acrylic colour. It is a rich gold yellow colour with green undertones. A useful colour for floral paintings. While the colour green evokes nature and renewal, its pigments have been some of the most poisonous in history.

A rich green colour with a yellow tint. A mixed pigment colour, it was originally created by 19th c English botanist illustrator William J Hooker, a botanical illustrator working for the Royal Horticultural Society who needed a dark green colour for painting the many dark green leaves he had to paint.

A stable all-round black colour with brown undertones and excellent tinting powers. Its name stems from the traditional method for obtaining it - roasting elephant tusks. Swedish artist Anders Zorn is said to have used only ivory black, titanium white, cadmium red and yellow ochre. This quartet of colours is known as Zorn palette.
One of the oldest pigments. It is made of pure carbon, originally from the residual soot of burnt oil lamps. It is a black with a bluish tint, producing a variety of cool blue greys.

Lemon Yellow is a clear bright yellow colour. It is part of the Hansa pigments which were discovered in the early 1900s in Germany by the Hoechst company. The pigment known could consist of barium chromate, strontium chromate, or a mixture of lead chromate with lead sulphate.
Mixing White is an excellent white mixing colour. A combination of zinc and titanium, it is an opaque white colour.
Quinacridone Magenta is a rich deep violet red colour. It is based on the transparent Quinacridone pigment which was introduced in the 1950s.
Phthalo Green is a brilliant transparent green pigment with a blue undertone. Can be used to mix with crimson to create a rich black.
Process Magenta is a bright violet red acrylic colour. It is one of the basic primary colours. It is based on the transparent Quinacridone pigment.
Process Cyan is a bright blue acrylic colour. It is one of the basic primary colours. It is based on the intense blue Phthalocyanine pigment.
Process Yellow is a bright yellow acrylic colour. It is one of the basic primary colours. It is based on the brilliant yellow Arylide pigment.
Prussian Blue Hue is a deep rich blue colour, closely resembling genuine Prussian Blue. Prussian Blue was made by German chemist Diesbach around 1704 making it the first synthetic blue pigment.
A bright brown pigment. One of the oldest pigments, it can be found in prehistoric cave art. It is named after Siena, Italy where the pigment was sourced during the Renaissance.
A rich brown pigment made by the natural brown clays found in earth. It was named after Umbria, a region in Italy where it was mined.
Red Ochre is one of the oldest pigments used by man. Originally made from natural iron oxides found in the earth, it is an opaque brownish red pigment. It was often used in Michelangelo's drawings.
Sap Green is a bright mid-range green with a yellow undertone. Originally Sap Green was a lake pigment made from unripe Buckthorn berries.

A buttery oil that features excellent tinting strength, a high level of pigmentation for intense colours, and a uniform degree of gloss and thickness amongst colours. Easy to mix and use. These oils are great for beginners, students in advanced studies, and working artists.
Transparent Yellow is a bright clean yellow colour. It is a transparent colour with strong tinting properties.

Ultramarine is a rich transparent blue. It was created by French chemist Guimet in 1828 as a synthetic but chemically identical alternative to the expensive pigment derived from Lapis Lazuli. The pigment was considered more precious than gold. For centuries, the lone source of ultramarine was an arid strip of mountains in northern Afghanistan. Because of its prohibitive costs, the colour was traditionally restricted to the raiment of Christ or the Virgin Mary.

Vermilion Hue is a bright orange red colour. The genuine pigment was made from toxic mercuric sulphide and was known to the ancient Greeks and Chinese. It is an opaque colour. Titian used Vermilion to create the reds in the great fresco of Assunta, completed c. 1518.
Winsor Violet (Dioxazine) is a vivid mid-shade purple pigment. When undiluted, it can be used as a deep black. It is a transparent coal tar pigment.

Yellow Ochre is a warm yellow colour. Originally made from natural iron oxides found in earth, it is one of the oldest pigments used by mankind. A synthetic version became available in the 1920s. Ideal for mixing with other mineral pigments for sensitive greens or the subtle warming of flesh tones without adding shadow.

A synthetic lake pigment from the Madder plant, it was the first natural dye to be synthesised in 1868. It is a deep transparent red with a blueish undertone. Alizarin crimson paint was a favourite of television presenter Bob Ross and was used frequently on his popular and long-running show, ‘The Joy of Painting’.

Burnt Sienna is a rich brown pigment made by burning Raw Sienna. Named after Siena in Italy, where the pigment was sourced during the Renaissance, it is a transparent pigment with red-brown tones. It is one of the most useful colours in the palette. Mixed with Ultramarine it creates a warm Indigo, burnt umber hues, lovely greys, stormy sky colours, shadow colours and so on. With a yellow it creates raw sienna hues. With a phthalo blue it creates cool greys and browns. With a crimson it creates earthy indian reds and burnt reds...and so on. Alone, it creates a perfect skin tone.

A rich dark brown pigment, it is made from natural brown clays found in earth. It was named after Umbria, a region in Italy where it was mined. Burning the raw pigment intensifies its colour. The use of umber by artists dates back to our earliest image-making ancestors who smeared soil on cave walls as a suitable approximation for the auburn fur of beasts.

A cool yellow colour, Cadmium Lemon is a single pigment colour with excellent tinting abilities. Cadmium was discovered in 1817. Its stable opaque colours have made it a popular pigment ever since. Paul Gauguin painted ‘Breton Woman in Prayer’ in 1894 with a yellow lemon dress.

An opaque orange single pigment colour with high tinting strength and good covering abilities. ‘The Scream’ by Edvard Munch depicts a human figure whose face is distorted by an expression of overwhelming terror and anxiety - the landscape behind the figure consists of a fiery Cadmium Orange sky above a bleak body of water.

A single pigment colour, Cadmium Red is a mid-range red colour with strong tinting qualities. It is a highly stable, bold opaque pigment. Vermilion was a popular paint until its toxicity and expense caused most artists to switch to Cadmium Red. Matisse was much taken with this strong new red, which has excellent stability. He recounts that he attempted, unsuccessfully, to persuade Renoir to adopt a it in place of the traditional cinnabar.
A vivid bright red pigment. It is an opaque pigment and has excellent covering abilities. A by-product of the zinc industry, Cadmium was discovered in 1817.

A strong and deep yellow with a warm red mass tone. It is opaque with excellent tinting properties. Yellow was Vincent Van Gogh's favourite colour and was said to be the colour of “self expression.”  In some of his paintings, he restricted his palette to be composed almost entirely of yellows, as in ‘Sunflowers’.

Developed in 1805 and entered the English market in the 1860s. Its name derives from the Latin Caeruleum meaning sky-blue pigment. It is a bright blue pigment with green undertones. Monet's 'The Gare Saint-Lazare' (1877) is a mixture of cobalt blue, cerulean blue, synthetic ultramarine, emerald green and viridian.

A clean blue pigment discovered in 1802 by French chemist Louis Jacques Thenard as an alternative pigment to the expensive Lapis Lazuli blue. Vincent van Gogh declared to his brother Theo, 'Cobalt Blue is a divine colour and there is nothing so beautiful for putting atmosphere around things' - it makes sense then, that Cobalt Blue is used most masterfully, and famously, in van Gogh's 'The Starry Night'.

A paler, slightly greener colour to its sister Cobalt Turquoise. A careful blend of blue and green pigments, it is a delicate opaque colour. Cobalt Blue and Turquoise were used in Delacroix’s famous ‘Liberty Leading the People’ (1830).
A warm bright red colour. It is an opaque gouache colour. Red is not only one of the primary colours, it’s also one of the first colours used by artists—dating back to prehistory.

A deep blue pigment that can range from dark black to pale blue. Originally extracted from plants similar to blue woad used by the ancient Britons, it was synthesised in 1878 in Germany. It is one of the oldest blue pigments used universally. It has high tinting strength but may fade rapidly when exposed to strong sunlight. It is best used full strength and protected from ultraviolet light beneath a UV-protecting varnish or glass.

A stable all-round black colour with brown undertones and excellent tinting powers. Its name stems from the traditional method for obtaining it - roasting elephant tusks. Swedish artist Anders Zorn is said to have used only ivory black, titanium white, cadmium red and yellow ochre. This quartet of colours is known as Zorn palette.

A stable, basic black gouache. It is opaque and lightfast. Artist Simon Bull is known for his use of bright colour and expressive, gestural brushstrokes. In many of his paintings, Bull uses a jet black background to enhance his vibrant subjects.
One of the oldest pigments. It is made of pure carbon, originally from the residual soot of burnt oil lamps. It is a black with a bluish tint, producing a variety of cool blue greys.

Lemon Yellow is a clear bright yellow colour. It is part of the Hansa pigments which were discovered in the early 1900s in Germany by the Hoechst company. The pigment known could consist of barium chromate, strontium chromate, or a mixture of lead chromate with lead sulphate.
Light Purple is a pale purple colour. It is an opaque gouache colour. Purple is a colour closely associated with the Catholicism, symbolising both high rank and human suffering within the church.

Magenta is a rich deep violet red colour. It is a transparent pigment. The name Magenta comes from a lake colour named in 1859 after the battle in Magenta, Italy. Used by Mark Rothko in the painting entitled ‘Magenta, Black, Green on Orange’.
Marigold Yellow is an orange-yellow gouache. It is a fully permanent, semi-opaque colour similar to shades favoured by Vincent van Gogh.

Naples Yellow Deep is a warm opaque yellow pigment. Originally its name comes from natural deposits in Mount Vesuvius, Naples. Made artificially since the 15th c, it was part of the Old Masters' palette.
Orange Lake Light is a light reddish orange colour. It is a semi-opaque lightfast gouache. Similar to shade used by J M Turner in ‘Sun Setting over a Lake’ 1840.
Oxide of Chromium is an opaque willow green pigment. Though discovered in 1809 it was only made available for artists in 1862. Today, it is commonly used for camouflage clothing.
Highly transparent with a blue undertone, Permanent Alizarin Crimson is a vivid red colour. Introduced in 1994, it has been formulated as a highly permanent red pigment.
Perylene Violet is a light red pigment. Perylene is a modern synthetic organic pigment and was first available as a dye around 1912 before becoming available as an artist pigment in the late 1950s.

Permanent Rose is a bright rose violet colour. It is a transparent quinacridone pigment. A popular colour to mix with reds, oranges and yellows to create vibrant floral colours and to allow for subtle shifts in value and tone.
Perylene Black is a strong black pigment. It has an exquisite green undertone. It can be used straight or for green and blue mixtures.
Perylene Maroon is a dark maroon pigment. Perylene is a modern synthetic organic pigment and was first available as a dye around 1912 before becoming available as an artist pigment in the late 1950s.
Permanent Yellow Deep is a dark warm yellow colour. It is a semi-opaque permanent gouache.
Permanent White is a strong white colour. Based on Titanium pigments, it is an opaque colour.
Primary Blue is a bright blue gouache colour. It is one of the basic primary colours. It is an opaque colour based on the intense blue phthalocyanine pigment.
Primary Red is a bright violet red gouache colour. It is one of the basic primary colours and is semi-opaque.
Primary Yellow is a bright yellow gouache colour. It is one of the basic primary colours. It is based on the high tinting strength Quinophthalone yellow pigment.

Prussian Blue is a deep blue colour. It was made by German chemist Diesbach around 1704 making it the first synthetic blue pigment. It quickly gained favour as an alternative to genuine Ultramarine. It has very high tinting strength but is only fairly permanent to light and air. It's an Iron-hexacyanoferrate accidentally formed while experimenting with the oxidation of iron.
A bright brown pigment. One of the oldest pigments, it can be found in prehistoric cave art. It is named after Siena, Italy where the pigment was sourced during the Renaissance.
A rich brown pigment made by the natural brown clays found in earth. It was named after Umbria, a region in Italy where it was mined.
Red Ochre is one of the oldest pigments used by man. Originally made from natural iron oxides found in the earth, it is an opaque brownish red pigment. It was often used in Michelangelo's drawings.
Rose Tyrien is a strong purple-rose colour. It is a semi-opaque colour and its name Tyrien stems from the dye worn by the Roman Caesar
Spectrum Red is a strong red gouache colour. It is one of the basic primary colours and is an opaque pigment.

Spectrum Violet is a deep purple-blue colour. It is an opaque pigment. The colour violet only became common in modern art with the rise of the French Impressionists because pigments were not previously available or were too expensive.

Ultramarine is a rich transparent blue. It was created by French chemist Guimet in 1828 as a synthetic but chemically identical alternative to the expensive pigment derived from Lapis Lazuli. The pigment was considered more precious than gold. For centuries, the lone source of ultramarine was an arid strip of mountains in northern Afghanistan. Because of its prohibitive costs, the colour was traditionally restricted to the raiment of Christ or the Virgin Mary.
Ultramarine (Green Shade) is a rich deep transparent blue with green undertones, differing from the red undertones of French Ultramarine. French chemist Guimet created synthetic Ultramarine in 1828.

Viridian is a transparent emerald green colour. Named after the Latin for green 'viridis', it was first made in Paris by colourist Binet in 1838 as a replacement for the deadly Emerald Green. Its excellent permanence and lack of toxicity could replace all other greens, both ancient and modern. Monet’s ‘La Gare Saint-Lazare’ (1877) is a mixture of cobalt blue, cerulean blue, synthetic ultramarine, emerald green and viridian.
Winsor Blue is a deep intense blue which when undiluted, forms an inky blue-black. It is made from the modern pigment Phthalocyanine which was introduced in the 1930s.
Winsor Green is a brilliant transparent green pigment with a blue undertone. It is made from the modern pigment Phthalocyanine which was introduced in 1930s.
Winsor Violet (Dioxazine) is a vivid mid-shade purple pigment. When undiluted, it can be used as a deep black. It is a transparent coal tar pigment.

Yellow Ochre is a warm yellow colour. Originally made from natural iron oxides found in earth, it is one of the oldest pigments used by mankind. A synthetic version became available in the 1920s. Ideal for mixing with other mineral pigments for sensitive greens or the subtle warming of flesh tones without adding shadow.
Zinc white has a much colder, cleaner, whiter masstone than the best grades of lead white or titanium white.

A synthetic lake pigment from the Madder plant, it was the first natural dye to be synthesised in 1868. It is a deep transparent red with a blueish undertone. Alizarin crimson paint was a favourite of television presenter Bob Ross and was used frequently on his popular and long-running show, ‘The Joy of Painting’.

A cool yellow colour, Cadmium Lemon is a single pigment colour with excellent tinting abilities. Cadmium was discovered in 1817. Its stable opaque colours have made it a popular pigment ever since. Paul Gauguin painted ‘Breton Woman in Prayer’ in 1894 with a yellow lemon dress.
Similar to Cadmium Red Medium in mass tone, this napthol red is more transparent, bright, and slightly blue. Perfect for high key painting due to the bright oranges and pinks it can create.

Incredibly rich and opaque, this gorgeous red is a pure genuine Cadmium Red, warm, but also deeper in value, with an intensely captivating mass tone and softly warm tints. On the traditional colour wheel, it is considered to be a 'true red', close to vermilion. It is also considered a modern day replacement for vermilion, but it is more saturated (higher chroma) than genuine vermilion.

An intense red colour with orange undertones. It is an opaque single pigment colour with excellent tinting properties. The Zorn palette refers to a palette of colours attributed to the great Swedish artist, Anders Zorn (18 February 1860 – 22 August 1920). It consists of just 4 colours being yellow ochre, ivory black, vermilion and titanium white. Cadmium red light is commonly used in place of vermilion by modern day artists.

An opaque orange single pigment colour with high tinting strength and good covering abilities. ‘The Scream’ by Edvard Munch depicts a human figure whose face is distorted by an expression of overwhelming terror and anxiety - the landscape behind the figure consists of a fiery Cadmium Orange sky above a bleak body of water.

Yellow Ochre is a warm yellow colour. Originally made from natural iron oxides found in earth, it is one of the oldest pigments used by mankind. A synthetic version became available in the 1920s. Ideal for mixing with other mineral pigments for sensitive greens or the subtle warming of flesh tones without adding shadow.

The range of cadmium pigments, yellow, orange and red are basically cadmium yellow (cadmium sulfide) with some selenium added in place of sulfur (cadmium selenide). Monet used this colour extensively.
A single pigment colour. It is an opaque, bright yellow with excellent tinting properties. Many of Monet’s Water Lilies series of paintings utilise Cadmium Yellow Light.

A rich green colour with a yellow tint. A mixed pigment colour, it was originally created by 19th c English botanist illustrator William J Hooker, a botanical illustrator working for the Royal Horticultural Society who needed a dark green colour for painting the many dark green leaves he had to paint.
A brilliant Lime Green tone with a Yellow undertone that is ideal for use in landscapes and non-objective painting and an essential for low key painters.
Phthalo Blue is a deep intense blue which when undiluted, forms an inky blue-black. It is made from the modern pigment Phthalocyanine which was introduced in the 1930s.

Ultramarine is a rich transparent blue. It was created by French chemist Guimet in 1828 as a synthetic but chemically identical alternative to the expensive pigment derived from Lapis Lazuli. The pigment was considered more precious than gold. For centuries, the lone source of ultramarine was an arid strip of mountains in northern Afghanistan. Because of its prohibitive costs, the colour was traditionally restricted to the raiment of Christ or the Virgin Mary.

Developed in 1805 and entered the English market in the 1860s. Its name derives from the Latin Caeruleum meaning sky-blue pigment. It is a bright blue pigment with green undertones. Monet's 'The Gare Saint-Lazare' (1877) is a mixture of cobalt blue, cerulean blue, synthetic ultramarine, emerald green and viridian.

A clean blue pigment discovered in 1802 by French chemist Louis Jacques Thenard as an alternative pigment to the expensive Lapis Lazuli blue. Vincent van Gogh declared to his brother Theo, 'Cobalt Blue is a divine colour and there is nothing so beautiful for putting atmosphere around things' - it makes sense then, that Cobalt Blue is used most masterfully, and famously, in van Gogh's 'The Starry Night'.

A deep Magenta masstone with a definite Red undertone. Mixes cleanly to make a wide range of Violet tints and shades. Great for florals and sunsets. The colour violet only became common in modern art with the rise of the French Impressionists because pigments were not previously available or were too expensive.
A heavy opaque pigment, it is a dense black colour with a brown undertone. It is made from mineral iron oxide and was therefore named after the alchemical name for iron - Mars.

A vivid mid-shade purple pigment. When undiluted, it can be used as a deep black. It is made from a transparent coal tar pigment. It is the perfect starting point for Impressionistic colours whether mixed with Ultramarine Blue for bluer violets or with Magenta Quin Violet for warmer violets, or perhaps just used from the tube for deep dark purples.

Payne's Gray is a dark blue grey made from a mixture of Ultramarine, Mars Black and sometimes Crimson. It was named after the 18th c. water-colourist William Payne who created the mixture and often recommended it to his students as an alternative to plain black.
A rich brown pigment made by the natural brown clays found in earth. It was named after Umbria, a region in Italy where it was mined.

A rich dark brown pigment, it is made from natural brown clays found in earth. It was named after Umbria, a region in Italy where it was mined. Burning the raw pigment intensifies its colour. The use of umber by artists dates back to our earliest image-making ancestors who smeared soil on cave walls as a suitable approximation for the auburn fur of beasts.

Burnt Sienna is a rich brown pigment made by burning Raw Sienna. Named after Siena in Italy, where the pigment was sourced during the Renaissance, it is a transparent pigment with red-brown tones. It is one of the most useful colours in the palette. Mixed with Ultramarine it creates a warm Indigo, burnt umber hues, lovely greys, stormy sky colours, shadow colours and so on. With a yellow it creates raw sienna hues. With a phthalo blue it creates cool greys and browns. With a crimson it creates earthy indian reds and burnt reds...and so on. Alone, it creates a perfect skin tone.
A bright brown pigment. One of the oldest pigments, it can be found in prehistoric cave art. It is named after Siena, Italy where the pigment was sourced during the Renaissance.

A synthetic lake pigment from the Madder plant, it was the first natural dye to be synthesised in 1868. It is a deep transparent red with a blueish undertone. Alizarin crimson paint was a favourite of television presenter Bob Ross and was used frequently on his popular and long-running show, ‘The Joy of Painting’.

A brilliant transparent green pigment with a blue undertone. Invaluable for mixing. Add a cool or mid yellow for bright spring-greens, add a warm yellow for wonderful Sap greens. Add a crimson for the most amazing range of plum, aubergine, deep green and black hues. Add burnt sienna for pine greens. Add a blue for turquoise hues.
Venetian Red is an opaque deep red colour. An earth pigment, it was called Venetian Red after the quarry near Venice where the painter Titian sourced his earth reds.
A vivid red colour. Transparent, it is based on pyrrole, a pigment known for creating the iconic Ferrari red.

An extremely bright green hue that takes after its close colour wheel neighbour, lime green. ... pairs well with pinks that fall in the red violet range in the colour wheel. It is better suited as an accent because of its intense vibrancy.

Violet is a deep purple-blue colour. It is an opaque pigment. The colour violet only became common in modern art with the rise of the French Impressionists because pigments were not previously available or were too expensive.

The use of metallic finishes in art has a long and esteemed history that began with a technique known as gilding. The ancient Egyptians and Greeks used this process to add metallic lustre to their artworks and to emphasise particular features.

The use of metallic finishes in art has a long and esteemed history that began with a technique known as gilding. The ancient Egyptians and Greeks used this process to add metallic lustre to their artworks and to emphasise particular features.

The use of metallic finishes in art has a long and esteemed history that began with a technique known as gilding. The ancient Egyptians and Greeks used this process to add metallic lustre to their artworks and to emphasise particular features.
A a clean white pigment. It is the most opaque white. If you use a white that isn’t opaque enough it can cause troubles when you’re trying to block out different areas of your painting.

Lemon Yellow is a clear bright yellow colour. It is part of the Hansa pigments which were discovered in the early 1900s in Germany by the Hoechst company. The pigment known could consist of barium chromate, strontium chromate, or a mixture of lead chromate with lead sulphate.

A cool yellow colour, Cadmium Lemon is a single pigment colour with excellent tinting abilities. Cadmium was discovered in 1817. Its stable opaque colours have made it a popular pigment ever since. Paul Gauguin painted ‘Breton Woman in Prayer’ in 1894 with a yellow lemon dress.

A a bright opaque lemon yellow with excellent covering properties. Originally patented in 1924 by the pharmaceutical industry, it has been used by artists since the 1980s.  It is a beautiful cool light yellow very similar to Cadmium Yellow Light and has the same uses for the artist.
A single pigment colour. It is an opaque, bright yellow with excellent tinting properties. Many of Monet’s Water Lilies series of paintings utilise Cadmium Yellow Light.
Nickel Azo Yellow is a dark yellow colour. It is an opaque acrylic. It washes out to a lighter almost lemon yellow but has a deeper, slightly dirty masstone.

A warm yellow colour. It is a semi-transparent acrylic. The pigment was originally developed by the German Hoechst company in the early 1900s. Yellow was Vincent Van Gogh's favourite colour and was said to be the colour of “self expression.”  In some of his paintings, he restricted his palette to be composed almost entirely of yellows, as in ‘Sunflowers’.

The range of cadmium pigments, yellow, orange and red are basically cadmium yellow (cadmium sulfide) with some selenium added in place of sulfur (cadmium selenide). Monet used this colour extensively.

Extra rich and fully opaque, Cadmium Yellow Deep is a vibrant light orange with luminous golden yellow tints. It has a masstone of vivid orangey yellow, with an undertone displaying a rich orangey yellow. A strong opaque deep yellow which is sensitive to moisture and should not be used outdoors. Yellow was Vincent Van Gogh's favourite colour and was said to be the colour of “self expression.”  In some of his paintings, he restricted his palette to be composed almost entirely of yellows, as in ‘Sunflowers’.

A warm yellow colour with a reddish tint. It is a semi-transparent acrylic. The pigment was originally developed by the German Hoechst company in the early 1900s. Yellow was Vincent Van Gogh's favourite colour and was said to be the colour of “self expression.”  In some of his paintings, he restricted his palette to be composed almost entirely of yellows, as in ‘Sunflowers’.

An opaque orange single pigment colour with high tinting strength and good covering abilities. ‘The Scream’ by Edvard Munch depicts a human figure whose face is distorted by an expression of overwhelming terror and anxiety - the landscape behind the figure consists of a fiery Cadmium Orange sky above a bleak body of water.
A bright warm orange, Pyrrole orange is a semi-transparent colour. A single pigment colour, Pyrrole Orange is a clean mid-orange which mixes well with other colours.

An intense red colour with orange undertones. It is an opaque single pigment colour with excellent tinting properties. The Zorn palette refers to a palette of colours attributed to the great Swedish artist, Anders Zorn (18 February 1860 – 22 August 1920). It consists of just 4 colours being yellow ochre, ivory black, vermilion and titanium white. Cadmium red light is commonly used in place of vermilion by modern day artists.
Quinacridone Magenta is a rich deep violet-red colour. It is based on the Quinacridone pigment. The name Magenta comes from a lake colour named in 1859 after the battle in Magenta, Italy.
Perylene Violet is a light red pigment. Perylene is a modern synthetic organic pigment and was first available as a dye around 1912 before becoming available as an artist pigment in the late 1950s.

A vivid mid-shade purple pigment. When undiluted, it can be used as a deep black. It is made from a transparent coal tar pigment. It is the perfect starting point for Impressionistic colours whether mixed with Ultramarine Blue for bluer violets or with Magenta Quin Violet  for warmer violets, or perhaps just used from the tube for deep dark purples.

Ultramarine Violet is a rich purple colour. It is a derivation of French Ultramarine, a synthetic pigment created in 1828 by French chemist Guimet as an alternative to genuine Ultramarine. The colour violet only became common in modern art with the rise of the French Impressionists because pigments were not previously available or were too expensive.
A clean deep blue pigment. It is fully lightfast and is a transparent colour. It is a modern organic pigment. Similar to indigo but does not fade as much.

Ultramarine is a rich transparent blue. It was created by French chemist Guimet in 1828 as a synthetic but chemically identical alternative to the expensive pigment derived from Lapis Lazuli. The pigment was considered more precious than gold. For centuries, the lone source of ultramarine was an arid strip of mountains in northern Afghanistan. Because of its prohibitive costs, the color was traditionally restricted to the raiment of Christ or the Virgin Mary.

A clean blue pigment discovered in 1802 by French chemist Louis Jacques Thenard as an alternative pigment to the expensive Lapis Lazuli blue. Vincent van Gogh declared to his brother Theo, 'Cobalt Blue is a divine colour and there is nothing so beautiful for putting atmosphere around things' - it makes sense then, that Cobalt Blue is used most masterfully, and famously, in van Gogh's 'The Starry Night'.

A clean blue pigment discovered in 1802 by French chemist Louis Jacques Thenard as an alternative pigment to the expensive Lapis Lazuli blue. Vincent van Gogh declared to his brother Theo, 'Cobalt Blue is a divine colour and there is nothing so beautiful for putting atmosphere around things' - it makes sense then, that Cobalt Blue is used most masterfully, and famously, in van Gogh's 'The Starry Night'.
Phthalo Blue (Red Shade) is a deep intense blue with a red undertone. It is made from the modern pigment Phthalocyanine which was introduced in the 1930s.
Phthalo Blue (Green Shade) is a deep intense blue with a green undertone. It is made from the modern pigment Phthalocyanine which was introduced in the 1930s.

Developed in 1805 and entered the English market in the 1860s. Its name derives from the Latin Caeruleum meaning sky-blue pigment. It is a bright blue pigment with green undertones. Monet's 'The Gare Saint-Lazare' (1877) is a mixture of cobalt blue, cerulean blue, synthetic ultramarine, emerald green and viridian.

Developed in 1805 and entered the English market in the 1860s. Its name derives from the Latin Caeruleum meaning sky-blue pigment. It is a bright blue pigment with green undertones. Monet's 'The Gare Saint-Lazare' (1877) is a mixture of cobalt blue, cerulean blue, synthetic ultramarine, emerald green and viridian.
Olive green is a soft, brownish-green colour named after the tones of natural green olives. Useful in many landscape and floral paintings when combined with other colours.

A transparent acrylic colour. It is a rich gold yellow colour with green undertones. A useful colour for floral paintings. While the colour green evokes nature and renewal, its pigments have been some of the most poisonous in history.
A warm opaque white colour with strong brown undertones. Popular in portrait painting to create a realistic skin tone when combined with Burnt Sienna and Potters Pink.

Naples Yellow is an opaque pinkish-yellow pigment. Originally a lead antimonite pigment, it can be found in Babylon tiles dating 5th c BC. Its name comes from natural deposits found in Mount Vesuvius, Naples. Used by the Old Masters, it has been made artificially since the 15th c. The Babylonians used it on ceramics.

Naples Yellow Deep is a warm opaque yellow pigment. Originally its name comes from natural deposits in Mount Vesuvius, Naples. Made artificially since the 15th c, it was part of the Old Masters' palette.

Yellow Ochre is a warm yellow colour. Originally made from natural iron oxides found in earth, it is one of the oldest pigments used by mankind. A synthetic version became available in the 1920s. Ideal for mixing with other mineral pigments for sensitive greens or the subtle warming of flesh tones without adding shadow.
Yellow Iron Oxide is a soft warm brownish yellow. An earth pigment, it is one of the oldest colours used by mankind and is extremely permanent.

An earth pigment used since prehistoric times. It is a warm brownish yellow colour. It has been made synthetically since the 1920s. Gold accents can add an ethereal touch to any work of art and replicate paintings such as those by Gustav Klimt.
Quinacridone Gold is a dark warm yellow colour which was originally formulated for the car industry. It is a transparent colour and mixes well with other pigments.
A bright brown pigment. One of the oldest pigments, it can be found in prehistoric cave art. It is named after Siena, Italy where the pigment was sourced during the Renaissance.

Burnt Sienna is a rich brown pigment made by burning Raw Sienna. Named after Siena in Italy, where the pigment was sourced during the Renaissance, it is a transparent pigment with red-brown tones. It is one of the most useful colours in the palette. Mixed with Ultramarine it creates a warm Indigo, burnt umber hues, lovely greys, stormy sky colours, shadow colours and so on. With a yellow it creates raw sienna hues. With a phthalo blue it creates cool greys and browns. With a crimson it creates earthy indian reds and burnt reds...and so on. Alone, it creates a perfect skin tone.
Potter's Pink is a soft rose colour. It is a semi-opaque colour with excellent lightfast qualities. It is commonly used in ceramics and frescos, giving its name Potter's Pink.
A semi-opaque pearlescent white colour. The pearlescent effect is most effective when mixed with transparent colours and even more effective laid over a dark background.
Silver is a unique colour which, due to its unusual combination of pigments, creates a metal sheen closely resembling that of silver.
Silver is a unique colour which, due to its unusual combination of pigments, creates a metal sheen closely resembling that of silver.

A unique colour which, due to its unusual combination of pigments, contains a metal sheen resembling that of gold. Gold accents can add an ethereal touch to any work of art and replicate paintings such as those by Gustav Klimt.
Renaissance Gold is a semi-opaque acrylic colour. It is a unique colour which due to its unusual combination of pigments, contains a metal sheen resembling that of aged gold.

A unique semi-opaque acrylic colour which due to its unusual combination of pigments, contains a metal sheen resembling that of antique gold. Gold accents can add an ethereal touch to any work of art and replicate paintings such as ‘The Kiss’ by Gustav Klimt.
Pyrrole Red Light is a bright scarlet red colour. A lighter red to its sister colour Pyrrole Red, it is an opaque pigment with excellent lightfast qualities.

Incredibly rich and opaque, this gorgeous red is a pure genuine Cadmium Red, warm, but also deeper in value, with an intensely captivating mass tone and softly warm tints. On the traditional colour wheel, it is considered to be a 'true red', close to vermilion. It is also considered a modern day replacement for vermilion, but it is more saturated (higher chroma) than genuine vermilion.

Naphthol Red Light is a light warm red colour. It is semi-transparent. Napthol is a modern synthetic organic pigment developed in the early 20th century. It is a popular colour in the car industry. Rothko dabbled with untested pigments in his work incorporating two brand-new organic reds into his palette for a series of murals. Naphthol, had no ill effects while Lithol faded badly.
Pyrrole Red is a single pigment colour. It is a warm mid-range red, opaque and highly permanent. It is a medium red that has more chroma than cadmium red and is also opaque and permanent.
A rich dark red, Cadmium Red is an opaque single pigment colour. It can be used for dense layers or diluted for soft effect. A famous painting using this shade is van Gogh’s ‘Red Almond Blossoms’.
Quinacridone Red is a vivid mid-red colour. It is a transparent pigment.

Perylene Red is a dark violet red pigment. Perylene is a modern, synthetic organic pigment and was first available as a dye around 1912 before becoming available as an artist pigment in the late 1950s.

Naphthol Red Medium is a warm red colour. It is a semi-transparent acrylic. Napthol is a modern organic synthetic pigment developed in the early 20th century. Rothko dabbled with untested pigments in his work incorporating two brand-new organic reds into his palette for a series of murals. Naphthol, had no ill effects while Lithol faded badly.

Permanent Rose is a bright rose violet colour. It is a transparent quinacridone pigment. A popular colour to mix with reds, oranges and yellows to create vibrant floral colours and to allow for subtle shifts in value and tone.
Highly transparent with a blue undertone, Permanent Alizarin Crimson is a vivid red colour. Introduced in 1994, it has been formulated as a highly permanent red pigment.
Perylene Maroon is a dark maroon pigment. Perylene is a modern synthetic organic pigment and was first available as a dye around 1912 before becoming available as an artist pigment in the late 1950s.
Quinacridone Violet is a rich pinkish violet pigment. It is a clean strong colour. It is based on the transparent Quinacridone pigment.

Developed in 1805 and entered the English market in the 1860s. Its name derives from the Latin Caeruleum meaning sky-blue pigment. It is a bright blue pigment with green undertones. Monet's 'The Gare Saint-Lazare' (1877) is a mixture of cobalt blue, cerulean blue, synthetic ultramarine, emerald green and viridian.

A paler, slightly greener colour to its sister Cobalt Turquoise. A careful blend of blue and green pigments, it is a delicate opaque colour. Cobalt Blue and Turquoise were used in Delacroix’s famous ‘Liberty Leading the People’ (1830).

A blend of blue and green pigments. The name stems from the French 'Turquoise' for the semi-precious stone that was exported to Europe from Persia via Turkey. Cobalt Blue and Turquoise were used in Delacroix’s famous ‘Liberty Leading the People’ (1830).
Phthalo Turquoise is an intense blue-green pigment with a red undertone. It is a transparent pigment.
Phthalo Green (Blue Shade) is a brilliant transparent green pigment with a blue undertone.
Phthalo Green (Yellow Shade) is a brilliant transparent green pigment with a yellow undertone.

A semi-transparent bright green colour with a strong blue undertone. It was discovered by Swedish chemist Sven Rinman in 1780 by making a compound of cobalt and zinc. Recently researchers have discovered that this centuries-old pigment used for painting has special magnetic properties that could lead to a break through in the field of spintronics.

A semi-transparent bright green colour with a strong blue undertone. It was discovered by Swedish chemist Sven Rinman in 1780 by making a compound of cobalt and zinc. Recently researchers have discovered that this centuries-old pigment used for painting has special magnetic properties that could lead to a break through in the field of spintronics.

An opaque willow green pigment. Though discovered in 1809 it was only made available for artists in 1862. It is commonly used for camouflage clothing. Useful in landscapes and for dulling red colours and making browns and mossy colours. Can be mixed with Burnt Umber to make shadows.

A rich green colour with a yellow tint. A mixed pigment colour, it was originally created by 19th c English botanist illustrator William J Hooker, a botanical illustrator working for the Royal Horticultural Society who needed a dark green colour for painting the many dark green leaves he had to paint.
Perylene Green is a dark transparent green pigment. Undiluted, it is almost a black colour. Perylene is a modern synthetic organic pigment and was first available in the late 1950s.
Sap Green Permanent is a rich mid-range green with a yellow undertone. Originally Sap Green was a lake pigment made from unripe Buckthorn berries.
Light Red is a red earth pigment based on natural and synthetic iron oxide. It is an opaque colour with a brown undertone and is permanent.
Red Iron Oxide is an opaque, soft red colour. An earth pigment, it is one of the oldest colours used by mankind and is extremely permanent.
Quinacridone Burnt Orange is a brownish orange colour. It is a clean strong colour based on the transparent Quinacridone pigment.
Violet Iron Oxide is a soft transparent violet colour. An earth pigment, it is one of the oldest colours used by mankind and is extremely permanent.
A rich brown pigment made by the natural brown clays found in earth. It was named after Umbria, a region in Italy where it was mined.
A rich brown pigment made by the natural brown clays found in earth. It was named after Umbria, a region in Italy where it was mined.

A rich dark brown pigment, it is made from natural brown clays found in earth. It was named after Umbria, a region in Italy where it was mined. Burning the raw pigment intensifies its colour. The use of umber by artists dates back to our earliest image-making ancestors who smeared soil on cave walls as a suitable approximation for the auburn fur of beasts.
A soft grey colour traditionally including powdered slate pigments. It was developed by Winsor & Newton for the 19th century English artist Henry Davy, a pupil of famous water-colourist J S Cotman.
Made of graphite, it is a stable all-round opaque grey colour. Famously used by Whistler in his painting of his mother, ‘Arrangement in Grey and Black’.

Payne's Gray is a dark blue grey made from a mixture of Ultramarine, Mars Black and sometimes Crimson. It was named after the 18th c. water-colourist William Payne who created the mixture and often recommended it to his students as an alternative to plain black.

A stable all-round black colour with brown undertones and excellent tinting powers. Its name stems from the traditional method for obtaining it - roasting elephant tusks. Swedish artist Anders Zorn is said to have used only ivory black, titanium white, cadmium red and yellow ochre. This quartet of colours is known as Zorn palette.
A heavy opaque pigment, it is a dense black colour with a brown undertone. It is made from mineral iron oxide and was therefore named after the alchemical name for iron - Mars.
